stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on programming the AI, attacks, and camera for the oil-based boss, Morkmar. The stream also featured a significant discussion on his game design philosophy regarding player expectations for 100% completion in ROM hacks, which led to the impromptu creation of a community poll and the new idea of a 'perk' system. He also debugged a major framerate issue and interacted with his wife, Zeina, before leaving to attend a wedding.

development_findings.summary: Kaze spent a significant amount of time debugging the boss AI, only to realize he was editing the code for the wrong object, a common but frustrating development mistake.
development_findings.quote: Oh, I know what I did wrong. And I used the oil block instead of the oil block boss. No wonder it didn't work. I was not even editing the relevant code.

development_findings.summary: The game's framerate dropped to 30 FPS due to a new, supposedly faster code contribution from a collaborator named Silas. Kaze had to revert to an older version from GitHub to fix it.
development_findings.quote: Why is it 30 FPS? God damn it. This is actually Silas' code. He gave me a new version of this that is supposedly a lot faster. But it does not seem to work.

development_findings.summary: Kaze implemented and fine-tuned a custom camera for the Morkmar boss fight, adjusting its height and distance dynamically to keep both the boss and the platforms visible.
Kaze decided against adding a status effect (like being slowed down) to Mario after being hit by oil, opting for simple damage over time for falling in the pit to avoid implementation complexity.
development_findings.quote: I don't want to program an oil effect onto Mario.

development_findings.summary: In response to the 100% completion dilemma, Kaze conceptualized a 'perk' system. Players could find and equip one single perk at a time, found as a secret in the overworld, to subtly modify difficulty without becoming a full-blown RPG system.
development_findings.quote: If we have these badges just be findable in the overworld, and then you can just select one of them as like a special perk... I'm kind of fine with that. But having this be like a whole badge menu, I think that's too much RPG for Mario 64.

development_findings.summary: Kaze created a new wave attack animation for the boss, using sine wave calculations in the code to make the boss dip into the oil and resurface, creating a shockwave.
Kaze explained that Yoshi Coins were designed specifically to solve the problem of 100-coin stars, which often forced players to abandon a level's main objective to collect them all in one run.
development_findings.quote: The Yoshi coins just save. You don't have to collect them all in one go. So you can collect them and you never have the thought of, oh, I need to leave and come back.

context_findings.summary: Kaze articulated his design philosophy on player feedback, believing that developers should address players' negative feelings but ignore their proposed solutions, which are often misguided.
context_findings.quote: What people feel, in a way, is real. You can't change that fact. But their reasoning is most of the time stupid. You should just ignore people's reasoning. But you can never really ignore people's feeling.

context_findings.summary: Kaze feels that the ROM hacking community's expectation to be able to 100% complete a game limits his design freedom, preventing the inclusion of extremely difficult or obscure optional content common in official titles.
context_findings.quote: We can't put hard challenges without people complaining. We can't put super secret hidden stuff without people complaining. And I think that really takes away a lot of design space.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expressed a feeling of rapid personal and professional growth, stating he feels he is improving significantly in all his skills.
context_findings.quote: Dude recently I feel like I have been evolving. I'm just getting so much better at everything for some reason.

context_findings.summary: Kaze and his wife, Zeina, were preparing to attend a wedding, which required the stream to be shorter than usual. He expressed a personal dislike for weddings.
Kaze mentioned that he and Zeina plan to have children in the future but are waiting until they own a house first.
context_findings.quote: I think I'll just wait until I have kids to play with them. We need a house first. Having kids without a house is just stupid.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is working on another major project, a Banjo-Kazooie ROM hack, which currently prevents him from streaming development of 'Return to Yoshi's Island' more than once a week.

biobak.summary: Biobak provided a suggestion for the boss camera, asking if the boss should move down more at the start of its attack.
Kaze credited Biobak with the idea for the boss's metal teeth, which will be implemented as separate objects.
biobak.quote: That's a very good idea by Biobak.

zeina.summary: Zeina's presence on stream reveals a supportive and playful dynamic with Kaze; she prepared his meal, clarified a story he told, and engaged in lighthearted banter.
Zeina calls Kaze a picky eater, and he agrees, adding that he requires very large portions of food. She made him a large meal knowing he might be hungry at the wedding they were attending.
zeina.quote: You're very picky. But I also need like a huge amount of food. I can't just leave off the portion of like a 10 year old girl.

zeina.summary: Zeina and Kaze exchanged affectionate goodbyes on stream before she left to get ready for the wedding.
zeina.quote: Love you. Bye. Bye. Bye. Love you, too.

key_stories.title: The 30 FPS Bug
key_stories.summary: Kaze discovered a major FPS drop in the game, traced it back to a faulty optimization contributed by another developer, and fixed it by reverting to a previous version of the code from source control. This highlights the challenges of collaborative open-source development and the importance of version control.
key_stories.challenge: The player character's animations were suddenly running at 30 FPS instead of the target 60 FPS, making the game feel sluggish and broken.
key_stories.process: Kaze first noticed the framerate drop and immediately suspected a recent code change. He identified the new code from a contributor, Silas, as the likely culprit. After struggling with slow source control software, he successfully located and restored the previous, functional version of the code.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze reverted the problematic code provided by the contributor, successfully restoring the game to 60 FPS. He planned to inform the contributor that their optimization attempt had failed.
key_stories.key_quote: Why is it 30 FPS? God damn it. I don't know why he has 30 FPS again. This is actually Silas' code.

key_stories.title: The 100% Completion Dilemma
key_stories.summary: Kaze wrestled with the restrictive design space created by player expectations in the ROM hacking scene. Through community interaction and philosophical reflection, he developed the idea for a 'perk' system to give players control over difficulty, turning a design limitation into a potential feature.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze feels that the player expectation to 100% complete ROM hacks limits his ability to include very difficult or obscure optional content, a freedom that designers of official games enjoy.
key_stories.process: Kaze articulated the problem, citing another hack as an example of negative feedback on hard content. He engaged his community with a poll to confirm his hypothesis about player expectations. The results and chat discussion sparked the idea for a non-intrusive, single-perk system to address the issue.
key_stories.outcome: The discussion led to a potential solution: a 'perk' system. Players could find and equip a single perk hidden in the overworld to subtly alter difficulty, giving them agency and making challenges feel like a personal choice rather than a fault of the game.
key_stories.key_quote: We can't put hard challenges without people complaining. We can't put super secret hidden stuff without people complaining. And I think that really takes away a lot of design space.

key_stories.title: Debugging the Wrong Object
key_stories.summary: Kaze was stumped by a bug where his code changes for a boss weren't working. After a long period of frustrating debugging, he realized he was editing the wrong source file entirely, a classic developer mistake that cost him significant time.
key_stories.challenge: While programming the oil boss's behavior, none of Kaze's code changes were having any effect in-game, leading to significant frustration and confusion.
key_stories.process: Kaze spent a considerable amount of time tweaking AI parameters and animation calls, becoming increasingly perplexed as nothing changed. He reviewed his logic multiple times before the simple but critical error dawned on him.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze had a moment of realization and identified that he was editing the source file for a generic object instead of the specific boss object. Once he switched to the correct file, his changes worked immediately, and he was able to proceed with development.
key_stories.key_quote: Oh, I know what I did wrong. And I used the oil block instead of the oil block boss. No wonder it didn't work. I wasn't even editing the relevant code.

open_questions.context: Kaze proposed a system where players can find and equip a single 'perk' to modify difficulty, but he seemed uncertain how to integrate this into the game's world thematically.
questions: How do you envision integrating the 'perk' system thematically into the world of Yoshi's Island?
What would these perks be called or look like to fit the game's aesthetic?
How would you balance these perks to ensure one isn't a 'must-pick' and they genuinely offer different playstyles?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned he is working on a Banjo-Kazooie ROM hack, and that this project is the reason he can only stream development for 'Return to Yoshi's Island' once a week.
questions: How do you balance your time and creative energy between two major projects like this?
Do ideas or technical solutions from one project ever influence the other?
What is the long-term plan for the Banjo hack and how does it fit with your goals for RTYI?

open_questions.context: Kaze had to revert a performance optimization from a collaborator named Silas because it halved the game's framerate.
questions: Can you describe your process for integrating code from external contributors?
How do you handle situations where a contribution introduces a major bug?

questions: What was the 'wedding cart' that Zeina asked you about?
